description:
Penaeus chinensis, also known as the Chinese white shrimp or Chinese prawn, is a species of shrimp native to the coastal waters of East Asia, particularly in the Yellow Sea, East China Sea, and South China Sea.

Taxonomically, Penaeus chinensis belongs to the order Decapoda, family Penaeidae, and genus Penaeus. It is a crustacean with a segmented body, five pairs of walking legs, and a pair of antennae. The shrimp typically has a white or translucent body with a slight pink or orange tint, and can grow up to 20 centimeters in length.

Penaeus chinensis is an important commercial species, widely farmed and harvested for human consumption. It is adapted to live in a variety of marine habitats, including estuaries, bays, and coastal areas with sandy or muddy seabeds. The species plays a significant role in the ecosystem, serving as a food source for larger predators and contributing to the cycling of nutrients in the marine environment.
